did.abstract: Charles Abram Ellwood (1873-1946) established the Department of Sociology at Duke University in 1930, retiring in 1944. The papers feature incoming and outgoing correspondence, chiefly professional but with some personal exchanges; minutes and other records of Pi Gamma Mu; book and article manuscripts; speeches; news clippings and book reviews; and some photographs. There are some papers related to his teaching career, chiefly related to summer school appointments and his positions at Missouri and Duke. A microfilm copy of a scrapbook (circa 1900-1946) contains clippings from Ellwood's career. Professional topics in the papers cover discussion and criticism of Ellwood's books, articles, and views; international and U.S. sociology organizations; the sociology departments at the University of Missouri and Duke University; social ethics; criminology; the social function of religion; and the scientific and statistical approach to sociology. Issues in Ellwood's papers related to crises of the time include race relations; political systems and beliefs; Fascism; persecution of Jews in Europe; U.S. involvement in World War II; religion and ethics; militarism and pacifism; and compulsory conscription.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Charles Abram Ellwood established the Department of Sociology at Duke University in 1930. He was born in the rural community of Black Lake near Ogdensburg, New York, on January 20, 1873. Ellwood earned his bachelor's degree from Cornell University in 1896 and his Ph.D. from the University of Chicago. He married Ida Breckenridge in 1897. He continued his studies in Europe at the University of Berlin, Oxford University, and the University of London. Ellwood served as Head of the Department of Sociology at the University of Missouri and then moved to Duke University in 1930.

His numerous writings, such as Social Problems, a Sociology (1932) and The World's Need of Christ (1940), focus on social psychology, religion and ethics, social scientific methods, criminology, and the family. Heavily influenced by the work of Charles H. Cooley, Ellwood believed in social reform and human improvement through rational evolution, and was a supporter of eugenics to some degree. In 1912 or 1913, he gave a lecture at Missouri, "The Eugenics Movement from the Standpoint of Sociology," which was chosen as part of a book, Eugenics: Twelve University Lectures, published by the Dodd, Mead & Company in 1914.

Ellwood actively participated in several national and international organizations, inlcuding International Congress of Arts and Science, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Sociological Society, Pi Gamma Mu National Social Science Honor Society, the International Congress of Sociology, and the National Education Association. He served as advisory editor of the American Journal of Sociology and as associate editor of the Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology. Ellwood retired from Duke University in 1944; he died in Durham, N.C., September 25, 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folders contain background information on sociologist Charles H. Ellwood; correspondence files, chiefly professional with some family letters scattered through later years; some photographs; teaching materials; and a positive microfilm reel of Ellwood's scrapbook relating chiefly to his career. Correspondence is chiefly to and from colleagues, with many in European countries and in Japan. Some relate to publishing and service in organizations; others discuss sociological issues, often at length. Exchanges between long-time colleagues or former students are more personal, particularly as infirmities and losses come with advanced age.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a 4-page typescript of "Circular issued by Brigadier General Isaac Ellwood on taking command of the 11th Brigade of New York State Infantry, April 4th, 1829." This is followed by several copies of Ellwood's resume`, list of publications, his autobiographical essay, with a few fragment pages attached, and several copies of a lengthy letter from an Ellwood cousin with a genealogy of various branches of the Ellwood family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chief item of interest is one 34-page soft-bound typescript bibliography of Ellwood's writings and writings about him, compiled in 1944 by Duke reference librarian MaryVie Cramblitt, with preface, introduction, and index. Also includes small group of loose sheets containing lists of publications by sociology faculty at Duke University, 1937-1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Begins with early education materials, including 1890 society yearbook from Ogdensburg Academy and Ellwood's 1890 graduation certificate. Subsequent materials include publicity about Ellwood's writings, short articles by Ellwood and others, clippings, letters to the editor, cards, tickets, and event programs. Arranged in rough chronological order. Oversize State Department passports and other certificates removed to oversize housing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of these items speak to wartime concerns. Topics include morality and war; conscription; atomic power; integration; and socialism/cooperatives. Titles from which clippings were taken include: The Catholic Worker; Reporter; The New Leader; The Orphan's Friend and Masonic Journal; Congressional Record; Pi Gamma Mu; Independent Woman; Harvard University Gazette; The Italian Mail; The Llano Colonist; and The Nation. Not arranged in date order. Oversize items have been separated and rehoused.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original order has been retained. Contains a wide variety of genres, chiefly short writings, mostly academic. Many reflect on significant issues of the day, including race, violence, religious and civil freedom, political society, pacifism, and war. Other folders document Ellwood's role in professional organizations. This series includes many of Ellwood's writings, most notably book reviews and letters to the editor; other pieces are found in the Writings series. Folder contents are arranged in rough chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An assortment of writings by Ellwood, chiefly letters to the editor, small essays, some reviews, poems, and fliers for Ellwood's early lectures. A few are in German. Most of these materials date from his Missouri days. Of interest are two pieces on race: one is a 1945 declaration by the INTERdependence, Inc., of Los Angeles, "Racial Appreciation: a Practical Approach," a one-sheet detailed proposal for an emblem for businesses and non-profits who do not condone discrimination on the basis of "human pigmentation." The other is a public statement by Ellwood following a remark he made about lynching and its relation to a community's morals to a class on criminology. Oversize chart separated and rehoused.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original order has been retained. Contains academic writings by Charles Ellwood in the form of chapter drafts, articles, editorials, lectures, and speeches, many with annotations, almost all relating to sociology and related academic topics. Many speak to significant issues of the day, including race relations, eugenics, and political society. Later pieces from the 1930s and early 1940s reflect the issues of totalitarianism, religious conflict, and war. This series includes many of Ellwood's writings, most notably book reviews and letters to the editor; other pieces are found in the Writings series. Folder contents are arranged in rough chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Presidential addresses, lectures, and various speeches. Includes his retirement speech at Duke. The earliest is titled "The marks of a sociological method that shall be adequate to construct a scientific basis for social control," written for Dr. Georg Simmel, the University of Berlin. One lecture from 1924 is on "Intolerance," and mentions the Ku Klux Klan. The last, "Valedictory," is Ellwood's retirement speech.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prefaced by several early pieces, some relating to the economic crises of the 1930s, including a revised draft of the Home Colonies Plan by Princess Lazarovich (born Eleanor Calhoun) submitted to President Roosevelt. There are materials from the Emergency Peace Campaign of 1936 and post-war peace efforts. There are a group of short editorials or lectures by Ellwood on the war, militarism, peace efforts, and totalitarianism. Also includes "Adjustment of the College Curriculum to Wartime Conditions and Needs, Report No. 3. Sociology," several pages with directions from the U.S. Office of Education, 1942.
